The question isn't can it be built for $6 billion, but will it really work, and can it be built for less than the $68 billion the California High Speed Rail project is estimated to cost, while giving superior lower cost service. The fact that it relies on commercially viable existing technologies that can be found in airliners, factories, highways, buildings, roller coasters, EV's, pipelines, and air hockey tables across America, strongly indicates that it might just work. The cost of finding out would be trivial compared to what we blew in Iraq.

Short staffing, and horrible work schedules are two of the main reasons I quit hospital nursing after only one year on the job.  (And after 4 1/2 years of education.)  The stress was unbelievable.  I seriously think that single year of work as a floor nurse aged me terribly.  I think a good, competent nurse is worth high respect, a good salary, and decent working conditions - including proper staffing and creative scheduling.  That is the only way we will get good, competent nurses.  It is true, our lives depend on it.

Alierias:

As I have used before as an example: Last year I computed my taxes according to reality, and paid quite a hefty sum. Then I computed them as though the EXACT same household income were that of a married couple with two kids. The difference: more than $700 a month.

That is $8,700 in spendable, after-tax cash that is taken from me compared to what is taken with a household with kids that posts the exact same income level as I do.

That is not my total tax bill, mind you, just the difference between the tax liability due to preferences given to parents and kids. Year after year after year.

I don't believe their value to society is that much greater than my value. I don't mind paying my fair share for infrastructure, for health, for research and regulatory affairs, for education and the general welfare. I do greatly resent that people feel entitled to take that much more from single, childfree, just because it's been deemed that we don't "need" as much of our income. I want to spend my wages on things that have meaning to me, just like anyone else.

What I am asking is to pay the same percentage of my income in taxes as the married and/or childed. We all contribute to society in various ways and my contributions in the realm of philanthropy, volunteerism, helping elderly friends and relatives, being environmentally conscious, etc. are just as important and far-reaching as the production of extra human beings.
People can pay for their own children.

@Kent: You assume that the normal doctor-patient relationship appends when the doctor is in the employ of the team, by dint of who pays them. One of the things that the Yankee$ revealed is that Rodriguez can NOT solicit a second opinion without the permission of the team. THAT is certainly outside the norm for the US medical establishment, where the right to a second opinion is routine and protected under law (ie insurance companies are *required* to allow the patient to seek one). What else does his contract or the CBA change? I would submit that we have little to no idea.

This is better than the circus. Does anyone seriously think that the Yankees would or could deliberately withhold information from Alex Rodriguez about his medical issues?

"During the 2012 playoffs, Tacopina said, the Yankees hid from Rodriguez that a magnetic resonance imaging test had revealed that he had a torn labrum, essentially a hole in his hip, and continued to play him even though he was struggling mightily."

The primary medical, legal and moral obligations of Alex Rodriguez's doctor and medical professionals assisting that doctor are to provide Rodriguez with the best medical care and advice. That includes telling Rodriguez about the results of an MRI. The doctor or doctors involved had to tell Rodriguez personally about the results of the MRI. The Yankees don't get to hide MRI results from Rodriguez for any reason. Randy Levine and the Steinbrenners are not the patient and they do not have any right to first hear results of medical tests on A-Rod. They also have no right and likely no practical way to withhold information on such tests from A-Rod.

And why would the Yankees not want A-Rod to ever play for them again? They would still have to pay the rest of his salary even if he retired. Why withhold this info from A-Rod? It does the team no good.

Note that Tacopina is making all these accusations. A-Rod says nothing and so can't be accused later of lying or being misleading.

I hope this whole mess blows up even more in A-Fraud's face.

I had dizziness, more like vertigo. It was caused by a virus that attacked my middle ear. It took a long time to go away. You have to cut out all caffeinated beverages. Or at least reduce them. If you have this it will never show up on any tests. Time, rest and anti inflammatory agents like Ibuprofen help.

Everyone has a lot of good advice for finding balance?. I have been an RN for 33 years. Now I am in hospice nursing. People get sick when they do not listen to their bodies. They just run faster, drink more coffee, ignore it. What you need to do is a lot of deep breathing and take a few minutes to relax each day notnjust when you are aboutbto collapse. Read Herbert Benson's book The Relaxation Response. It works.

Eat healthier and slower. Dinner should be an event. Drink water. Walk more. Go out in nature. Have a connection with people outside of work. Get a dog. Find a passion that creates flow ( flow is when you forget all about time and place) Sing in the car. Notice small things that bring a smile to your face. Give up pettiness. Love someone unconditionally. Have faith in something. Escape occasionally. Act silly often. Do something nice for a stranger. Mend broken fences. Be kind. Always be kind. Kindness has a calming effect. Hug people. Smile more. Find something or someone that makes you laugh.

Our lives are a blink in time. Enjoy it all. Don't miss out on your own life.

Mandatory contributions to a PAC are illegal.  But this writer raises the tough issue of how much pressure constitutes "mandatory".  This is one of my major problems with how PACs work in practice.

Corporate sponsored giving to a PAC or the United Way is part of the culture of the organization you joined. Companies are permitted to establish whatever legal internal practices they believe are beneficial to the company.  If you don't like giving to the PAC or the United Way, don't.  But, your nonparticipation in a company sponsored program may hurt you.  Many companies institute dress codes which cost employees money and dictate how they must appear at work. If you don't dress the way the company wants it may hurt you. In the end you join a sort of club when you accept employment from a company. That club can change the rules and you may not like it, but short of quitting or pushing for governance (company policy) to prohibit the actions you don't think appropriate within a private company, you have no choice but to accept the culture or accept the consequences.

I worked in a corporation that had de facto mandatory United Way. including mid level supervisors who went desk to desk to collect the envelopes (later the monitoring was electronic, even worse). But the final straw for me was the day after bonuses were awarded, when a new CEO sent an email with percentage suggested contributions to the company PAC, which distributed funds in accordance with the views of sr mgmt and not those of the majority of employees.

One should never underestimate the power of direct supervisors. I had one who expected attendance at post work drinking sessions, with one's entire family at his wife's Christmas party, and at random group outings such as concerts. Failure to partake of these "freebies" with enthusiasm was bad for one's prospects.

Well, it beats making money on war via the military industrial complex, something the Republicans have down to a fine art.

Bret Winter

But having a member of your staff who made "politically incorrect" statements about race, who then resigns? I'm referring of course to Jack Hunter.

How does that compare to having members of your staff who may be married to people who send sexual messages over the internet? I'm referring of course to Hilary.

In neither case should the indiscretions of staff members reflect on politicians themselves.

We live in a society dominated by scandal. The NY Times often reads like the National Enquirer. Why can't we focus on genuine issues?

Maybe having a staff member who said something once that was politically correct, or even factually wrong, is a bonus.

After all, political correctness prevents politicians from facing the real issues.
